abstract: Google is being upfront about its self interest in building public pressure for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum for new high-speed wireless Internet access. The airwaves, known as “white spaces,” will be unused after TV stations switch to all digital broadcasts next February, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to decide their fate soon.
snippet: Google is being upfront about its self interest in building public pressure for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum for new high-speed wireless Internet access. The airwaves, known as “white spaces,” will be unused after TV statio...
lead_paragraph: Google and other technology giants like Microsoft, Intel and Dell, have long pushed for a plan to allow soon-to-be-vacant broadcast spectrum to be used to provide new high-speed wireless Internet access networks. The airwaves, known as “white spaces,” will be unused after TV stations switch to all digital broadcasts next February, and the Federal Communications Commission is expected to decide their fate soon.

headline.main: Google Starts an Advocacy Campaign for More Unlicensed Spectrum

abstract: Timo Paloheimo, a blogger in Finland, has come up with a clever idea: Google Minus Google. The site is simply a way to use the Google search engine but see results that filter out Google domains like Knol, YouTube, Blogger, Orkut and many others.
snippet: Timo Paloheimo, a blogger in Finland, has come up with a clever idea: Google Minus Google. The site is simply a way to use the Google search engine but see results that filter out Google domains like Knol, YouTube, Blogger, Orkut and many others.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE 8:23 PM Added comment from Google

headline.main: Want Google Search Results Without Google Sites?

abstract: HTC, a Taiwanese cellphone maker, received U.S. regulatory approval Monday for the first phone that uses Google’s Android software. The clearance paves the way for T-Mobile to offer the device during the holiday selling season.
snippet: HTC, a Taiwanese cellphone maker, received U.S. regulatory approval Monday for the first phone that uses Google’s Android software. The clearance paves the way for T-Mobile to offer the device during the holiday selling season.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we told you that Taiwan-based HTC, one of the largest mobile device makers in the world, was readying the first smart phone to use Google’s Android operating system.

headline.main: A ‘Dream’ Come True: U.S. Approves the First Google Phone
